raw_text:
Teens 'know little' of politics
 
 Teenagers questioned for a survey have shown little interest in politics - and have little knowledge.
 
 Only a quarter of 14-16 year olds knew that Labour was the government, the Tories were the official Opposition and the Lib Dems were the third party. Almost all could identify Tony Blair, but only one in six knew who Michael Howard was, and just one in 10 recognised Charles Kennedy. The ICM survey interviewed 110 pupils for education watchdog Ofsted. Nearly half those pupils polled said it was not important for them to know more about what the political parties stand for. And 4% of those questioned thought the Conservatives were in power - while 2% of them believed the Lib Dems were. The survey also looked at issues of nationality. It found the Union flag and fish and chips topped the list of symbols and foods associated with being British. Many of the pupils also looked on themselves as English, Scottish or Welsh, rather than British; while the notion of being European hardly occurred to anyone.
llama3.2:1b:
Teens have little knowledge and interest in politics.
Only 25% knew Labour's official stance, Tories were the opposition, and Lib Dems were third party.
Fewer than a quarter had seen Tony Blair, just over half knew Michael Howard, and fewer than 10 recognized Charles Kennedy.
Only one in six knew who Michael Howard was, while 1 in 10 recognised Charles Kennedy.
llama3.2:3b: Teenagers aged 14-16 have little interest in politics and knowledge about parties. Only a quarter knew the names of Labour, Tories, and Lib Dems. Most recognized Tony Blair but not other politicians. Nearly half said they didn't need to know more about party stances. The Union flag and fish and chips were identified as symbols of Britishness.
gemma2:2b: Teenagers show low interest in politics and have limited knowledge of political parties and their stances. Most lack awareness of party affiliations like Labour, Tories, and Lib Dems, and few identify politicians such as Michael Howard or Charles Kennedy. Nearly half of teenagers believe it's unimportant for them to understand political parties' policies. Additionally, many associate the Union flag and fish and chips with British identity, with fewer considering themselves European.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Teenagers are not particularly interested in politics because they don't know much about it, according to a survey. Nearly half of 14-16-year-olds can identify some political parties and figures, but only one in six knows who Michael Howard was or Charles Kennedy. Most pupils polled thought the Conservatives were in power, while those who believed the Lib Dems were didn't think so. The survey also looked at symbols and foods associated with being British, like the Union flag and fish and chips. Many pupils also identified themselves as English, Scottish, or Welsh rather than British.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Teens have minimal knowledge of politics and show little interest in it, with only 25% understanding that Labour is in power, and 16% identifying Michael Howard. They also know Tony Blair but not Charles Kennedy or the Lib Dems, and most see themselves as British rather than European.
qwen2.5:3b: Teens 'know little' of politics - only a quarter know Labour was government, Tories were Opposition, and Lib Dems third party. Few recognize Michael Howard and Charles Kennedy. One in six believe Conservatives are in power, one in 40 think Lib Dems govern. Survey shows teens lack knowledge and interest in political parties; half see importance of knowing about them. National symbols and foods like Union flag and fish and chips top list, but only 1% consider themselves British, 98% identify as English, Scottish, or Welsh, none relate to being European.
opencoder:1.5b:
The key ideas and details from the text are:

1. Teenagers 'know little' of politics: This statement is about the importance of knowledge in understanding and voting in politics.

2. Only a quarter of 14-16 year olds knew that Labour was the government, the Tories were the official Opposition and the Lib Dems were the third party: These are the key insights into the roles of different political parties in shaping future generations's choices.
smollm:1.7b: The survey showed that teenagers have little interest in politics and know very little about the political parties. Only a quarter of 14-16 year olds knew that Labour was the government, the Tories were the official Opposition and the Lib Dems were the third party. Almost all could identify Tony Blair, but only one in six knew who Michael Howard was, and just one in 10 recognized Charles Kennedy. The survey also found that many of the pupils thought the Conservatives were in power - while the Lib Dems were not known to them.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, so I have this text about teenagers not knowing much about politics. The user wants a summary that's concise, only including key ideas and details. Let me read through it again to make sure I get all the main points.

Hmm, first sentence says teens don't know little about politics. Then it mentions a survey with kids between 14-16 years old. They showed little interest in politics and didn't have much knowledge of how political parties work. The text lists who the major parties are: Labour, Tories, and Lib Dems. It also talks about what teenagers could identify or know—like Tony Blair and Michael Howard but less so on others like Charles Kennedy.

Next part is about Ofsted survey: 110 kids were interviewed. Only half said it's not important for them to learn more about politics. One quarter thought Conservatives are in power, while a fifth thought Lib Dems are. They also looked at patriotic symbols—Union flag and fish and chips were top choices. The text notes that many kids identified as British rather than other nationalities and didn't think of themselves as European.

I need to condense this into a summary without any explanations or extra info. I'll keep the key points: teens don't know much about politics; survey results show they don't want to learn more; list of political parties, knowledge they have, symbols associated with Britishness, and nationality issues. Make sure it's clear and flows well.

Wait, the user specified only the summary in plain text without any explanations or formatting. So I should focus solely on the main ideas, numbers like "a quarter" and percentages, but not mention why those numbers are significant unless they're part of the key points.
</think>

teens do not understand much about politics; a survey of 14-16 year olds showed little interest in political topics; they knew that labour, Tories, and lib demps were government parties and the opposite were the opposition; teens could identify with Tony Blair but only one sixth knew Michael Howard's name, and one tenth knew Charles Kennedy's; 50% said knowing more about politics was not important; four percent believed Conservatives are in power, while 2% thought Lib demps were; the survey highlighted symbolic and nationality issues—Union flag, fish and chips as symbols for Britishness; many identified as English, Scottish, or Welsh rather than British; and few saw themselves as European.
tinyllama:1.1b: Several teenagers surveyed lack knowledge of politics and had little interest in political figures. Only a quarter could identify Labour as the government and almost all could name Tony Blair but only one in six knew who Michael Howard was, while only one in ten recognised Charles Kennedy as opposition leader. The survey found that nearly half of those interviewed did not think knowing more about political parties' stands would be important for them to make informed decisions regarding their lives and society. Only 4% believed the Conservatives were in power while over 2% believed the Lib Dems held it. Fewer than one in five had an opinion on the Union flag or fish and chips as national symbols, with many viewing themselves as British rather than English or Scottish or Welsh.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Teenagers tend to know little about politics, according to a recent survey conducted by ICM for Ofsted, the education watchdog. The ICM surveyed 110 pupils aged 14-16 in the UK and found that only 2% of them thought the Conservatives were currently in power, while another 2% believed the Lib Dems were. Furthermore, a significant number of teenagers do not seem interested in politics at all - just over a quarter (27%) did not know the names of the major political parties. The survey also showed that many teenagers are unfamiliar with important symbols and foods associated with being British.
phi:2.7b: A survey shows that most teenagers have little knowledge about politics and even less interest in it. Only a small percentage of them can identify key political figures or understand what the different parties stand for. The survey also found that many pupils see themselves as English, Scottish or Welsh rather than British, and are not particularly interested in the Union flag or traditional British foods like fish and chips.
orca-mini:3b: Teenagers surveyed for a political watchdog showed little interest in politics, knowledge, and identification of political parties. Only 25% knew that Labour was the government, 33% knew that the Tories were the official Opposition, and 17% identified Charles Kennedy. However, only 4% thought the Conservatives were in power.
hermes3:3b: You 14-16yos show low interest/knowledge in politics, knowing only a quarter about gov parties.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Teenagers have little knowledge about politics, with only a quarter aware of major parties' roles and names. Nearly half believe it's not important to know political party stands, and some incorrectly identify British identity symbols and nationalities.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Teenagers surveyed showed little interest or knowledge of politics. Only a quarter of 14-16 year olds knew the roles of the main political parties, and while most recognized Tony Blair, few identified Michael Howard or Charles Kennedy. Nearly half felt it was unimportant to understand party policies, and some mistakenly believed the Conservatives or Lib Dems were in power. The survey also explored national identity, finding that the Union flag and fish and chips were seen as British symbols, while many students identified more with their individual nations than as British or European.
stablelm2:1.6b: Teens show minimal interest in politics with only a quarter of year olds understanding basic political terminology. Most young people cannot identify key figures like Tony Blair and Michael Howard. Only 1/6 knew who Michael Howard was and one in 6 recognized Charles Kennedy. Nearly half the pupils questioned by Ofsted for education watchdog said it's not important to know more about political parties' standpoints. 4% of respondents believed Conservatives were in power, while only 2% thought the Lib Dems had control. The survey also examined national identity, revealing symbols and foods associated with Britishness. Many young people identify as English, Scottish or Welsh rather than British, and the concept of being European is not widely recognized.
granite3.1-dense:2b: A survey of 14-16 year-old students by Ofsted reveals limited political awareness. Only a quarter could correctly identify key parties: Labour as government, Tories as opposition, and Lib Dems as the third party. Familiarity with leaders varied significantly; Tony Blair was recognized by nearly all, while Michael Howard and Charles Kennedy were known by only one in six and 10% respectively. Nearly half of these students deemed political knowledge irrelevant to their lives. The survey also explored national identity, with the Union flag, fish and chips, and Britishness ranking highest. Pupils more often identified as English, Scottish, or Welsh than as European, indicating a strong sense of national belonging tied to geography over European unity.
reference: The survey also looked at issues of nationality.Many of the pupils also looked on themselves as English, Scottish or Welsh, rather than British; while the notion of being European hardly occurred to anyone.Only a quarter of 14-16 year olds knew that Labour was the government, the Tories were the official Opposition and the Lib Dems were the third party.The ICM survey interviewed 110 pupils for education watchdog Ofsted.
